articles.headline: 5 Israelis Killed in Bulgaria; Netanyahu Blames Iranians
articles.snippet: A bus carrying Israeli tourists exploded in a fireball outside an airport in Bulgaria, and an aide to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Iran was behind the attack.
articles.abstract: A bus carrying Israeli tourists exploded in a fireball outside an airport in Bulgaria, and an aide to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Iran was behind the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A tour bus carrying beachbound Israeli vacationers exploded in a fireball on Wednesday outside an airport in the Bulgarian city of Burgas, killing at least six people and wounding dozens more in what Bulgaria, Israel and the United States called a terrorist bomb attack. Israel quickly blamed Iran and promised a firm response.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Matthew Brunwasser

articles.headline: Pay by Voice? So Long, Wallet
articles.snippet: The Pay With Square service makes transactions easier than ever. If a retailer has your name and photo in its system, you only have to announce yourself to pay your bill.
articles.abstract: The Pay With Square service makes transactions easier than ever. If a retailer has your name and photo in its system, you only have to announce yourself to pay your bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lot of the things we do today will make our grandchildren burst out laughing. Yes, we used to drive to a store to rent a movie. Yes, there were huge patches of America where you couldn’t get a cellphone signal. Yes, we used to pay for things with pieces of green paper and plastic rectangles.

articles.headline: Economic Fears Hurting Obama, Poll Indicates
articles.snippet: Some 39 percent now say they approve of the way the president is handling the economy, and 55 percent say they disapprove.
articles.abstract: Some 39 percent now say they approve of the way the president is handling the economy, and 55 percent say they disapprove.
articles.lead_paragraph: Declining confidence in the nation’s economic prospects appears to be the most powerful force influencing voters as the presidential election gears up, undercutting key areas of support for President Obama and helping give his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, an advantage on the question of who would better handle the nation’s economic challenges, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Retirees Wrestle With Pension Buyout From General Motors
articles.snippet: Retirees who were offered pension buyouts from General Motors are finding the decision, a lump-sum check or continued monthly payments, anything but simple.
articles.abstract: Retirees who were offered pension buyouts from General Motors are finding the decision, a lump-sum check or continued monthly payments, anything but simple.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVI, Mich. — For weeks, John and Kathy Matthews have agonized over the choice: accept $818,000 in a lump sum from General Motors to buy out Mr. Matthews’s pension or keep collecting a check of $4,854 a month.

articles.headline: Denied Nickelodeon, DirecTV’s Youngest Clients Find Substitutes
articles.snippet: Because of a corporate spat, Nickelodeon, owned by Viacom, has disappeared from DirecTV’s lineup, giving the Disney Channel, the Cartoon Network and other channels an edge.
articles.abstract: Because of a corporate spat, Nickelodeon, owned by Viacom, has disappeared from DirecTV’s lineup, giving the Disney Channel, the Cartoon Network and other channels an edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Threats of television programming blackouts have become begrudgingly accepted by adults who know what these financial fights are all about.

articles.headline: Syrian Rebels Hone Bomb Skills to Even the Odds
articles.snippet: The attack on President Bashar al-Assad’s security chiefs aligned neatly with a tactical shift by rebels: the swift and successful adoption of makeshift bombs.
articles.abstract: The attack on President Bashar al-Assad’s security chiefs aligned neatly with a tactical shift by rebels: the swift and successful adoption of makeshift bombs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The lethal attack on Wednesday on President Bashar al-Assad’s senior security chiefs aligned neatly with a tactical shift that had changed the direction of Syria’s long conflict: the opposition fighters’ swift and successful adoption of makeshift bombs.

articles.headline: Years of Unraveling, Then Bankruptcy for a City
articles.snippet: Stockton, Calif., recently became the largest city in the country to declare bankruptcy, but evidence of its problems has been mounting for years.
articles.abstract: Stockton, Calif., recently became the largest city in the country to declare bankruptcy, but evidence of its problems has been mounting for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKTON, Calif. — This inland port on the San Joaquin River recently became the largest city in the country to declare bankruptcy, but evidence of its unraveling has been mounting for years.

articles.headline: Hezbollah Is Blamed for Attack on Israeli Tourists in Bulgaria
articles.snippet: American officials confirmed Israel’s assertions that the suicide bomber who killed five Israelis on a tour bus was a member of a Hezbollah cell.
articles.abstract: American officials confirmed Israel’s assertions that the suicide bomber who killed five Israelis on a tour bus was a member of a Hezbollah cell.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURGAS, Bulgaria — American officials on Thursday identified the suicide bomber responsible for a deadly attack on Israeli vacationers here as a member of a Hezbollah cell that was operating in Bulgaria and looking for such targets, corroborating Israel’s assertions and making the bombing a new source of tension with Iran.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Eric Schmitt
